comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content:
Tarpon, Octopus, and Bonita were C class subs, Grayling was D class. All were renamed on 17 November 1911 so this photo may have been taken prior to that date. I can't find a "Salem" but I wonder if that's really the Salmon, another D class. Subs were all named for fish at the time so "Salem" seems unlikely. Salmon was commissioned in Sept 1910 so that helps to further date the photo.

The photo was probably taken at Newport, Rhode Island, as that's where all these subs operated out of.

Source: Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships, via wikipedia.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the information and your source! The "Salmon" name makes sense given the other sub names. This negative is visually very similar to a negative dated Oct. 28, 1911, showing a naval review in NYC, www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163790702/.

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: The names are painted on the sides of the vessels, but there isn't enough resolution in the scans (or perhaps the original negative) to be able to read them.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: perfgeek: Try looking at the higher resolution version (tiff file) available at the persistent URL listed in the description.

comment.author: 27000124@N05
comment._content: Are those towers in the background on ships?

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Yes, those are lookout towers. They went out of style in the 1930s.

comment.author: 27000124@N05
comment._content: I'm afraid of heights. I get nervous just looking at those towers!

comment.author: 34854406@N07
comment._content:
I downloaded the high res tiff version of the file as suggested and ran a few simply image sharpening filters in Photoshop and uploaded the results here :

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/ultimatemike/3568909670/]

While still not 100% conclusive the name on the first sub does appear to have 6 letters not 5, further suggesting the name is Salmon rather than Salem.

comment.author: 55735558@N05
comment._content: You guys at The Library of Congress' do an amazing jobb! Thanks for keeping the past :)
